items.title: A flexible hippocampal population code for experience relative to reward
items.author: Lisa M. Giocomo
items.content: Sosa et al. find that hippocampal neural activity in mice encodes both environmental location and experience relative to rewards, spanning distances far from reward, through parallel and flexible population-level codes.

items.title: Suppression of binge alcohol drinking by an inhibitory neuronal ensemble in the mouse medial orbitofrontal cortex
items.author: Gilles E. Martin
items.content: This study demonstrates that high alcohol concentrations during binge drinking activate a small GABAergic neuronal ensemble in the medial orbitofrontal cortex, which subsequently reduces further alcohol consumption. This effect is mediated by the ensemble’s projections to the mediodorsal thalamus.

items.title: A route for cerebrospinal fluid flow through leptomeningeal arterial–venous overlaps enables macromolecule and fluid shunting
items.author: Antoine Drieu
items.content: The authors describe a mechanism for the clearance of macromolecules from cerebrospinal fluid in which macromolecules traverse from periarterial to perivenous spaces, at sites where intersecting leptomeningeal perivascular (arteriovenous) spaces overlap.

items.title: Spatial reasoning via recurrent neural dynamics in mouse retrosplenial cortex
items.author: Mark T. Harnett
items.content: Using a spatial reasoning task in mice, the authors show that retrosplenial cortex encodes spatial hypotheses with well-behaved recurrent dynamics, which can combine these hypotheses with incoming information to resolve ambiguities.

items.title: Noninvasive reduction of neural rigidity alters autistic behaviors in humans
items.author: Hidenori Yamasue
items.content: Autism is associated with inflexibility of brain dynamics. Watanabe and Yamasue show that TMS over the right superior parietal lobule while the brain is ‘stuck’ in a certain state reduces this rigidity and relieves various autistic traits.
